head.title: NOV. 28-DEC. 5: American Politics; Tsongas, Battling Cancer, Admits Candor Is Needed

hedline.hl1: NOV. 28-DEC. 5: American Politics; Tsongas, Battling Cancer, Admits Candor Is Needed

block.p: As he sought the Democratic Presidential nomination, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas made an issue of his nine-year battle against cancer, saying he had been disease-free since a bone marrow transplant in 1986. His doctors at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston concurred, minimizing the chances for a recurrence of his lymphoma, a cancer of the immune system. In fact, the lymphoma had recurred in 1987, making it unlikely that he had been cured.

Last week, Mr. Tsongas confirmed that he was facing a new fight. A growth in his abdomen turned out to be lymphoma; the cell type had changed from small cell to large cell, a not-unusual turn of events in the disease. The news was good and bad, he said at a press conference. Bad because the cancer had returned, apparently in a more aggressive cell type. Good because the lymphoma seemed confined to his abdomen and seemed likely to respond to chemotherapy and radiation.

Mr. Tsongas acknowledged having made mistakes in discussing his health, and said he realized that full disclosure was the only approach for a Presidential candidate. To avoid similar problems in the future, he urged Bill Clinton to set up a national commission to determine what a candidate must disclose.
